author: GittyAiden
title: Asian Regulators Launching Aviation Safety Data Sharing Initiative
text:
Asian Regulators Are Not Just Airing Their Safety Concernsâ€”Theyâ€™re Sharing Them! Ladies and gentlemen, hold onto your hatsâ€”or better yet, your life vestsâ€”because the aviation world is getting a bit of an upgrade in the safety department! Yes, you heard it right. Regulators from five Southeast Asian countriesâ€” Indonesia , Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and Thailandâ€”are embarking on a brand-new adventure: the Regional Aviation Safety Data and Information Sharing Initiative. Now, thatâ€™s a mouthful! I mean, why not just call it â€œOperation: Stay in the Air.â€
A Leap Towards the Skies of Safety ðŸƒâœˆï¸ Whatâ€™s sparked this sudden spree of cooperation, you ask? Well, it seems like the collective realization that â€œsafety firstâ€ might actually be worth taking seriously. You know what they say, â€œBetter safe than sorry,â€ especially when youâ€™re several miles above the ground, hurtling through the air at 500 miles per hour, right? So, these countries have decided that instead of each one flying solo (pun intended), theyâ€™d pool their resources and data to better identify safety hazards and trends. After all, if one country has a near miss, why not let the others know? Sharing is caring, especially when it involves aversion of imminent doom!
The Signing Ceremony: Give Us a Wave! ðŸ‘‹ On October 17, 2024, representatives from each country signed this historic agreement. Picture it: a group of aviation regulators gathered together like a gaggle of geese, bonding over their mutual goal of creating a safer aviation environment, all while deftly avoiding any discussions about what happened on those poorly reviewed airlines. Honestly, wouldnâ€™t you pay to watch that? (Not that I advocate for disaster tourism, mind you!).
The graphic accompanying the article serves as a reminder that sometimes, when it comes to aviation safety, cooperation really does look quite dapper! Flanked by their national flags, they lined up for the cameras, smiling like they just won a ticket to the best theme park in the world. Except, this ride is a lot safer and involves a lot less screaming.
Whatâ€™s on the Agenda? ðŸ“‹ So what exactly does â€œcollectively identifying safety hazardsâ€ involve? Well, itâ€™s like bringing your report card into a study group, showing everyone your areas of weakness, and hoping they donâ€™t mention your penchant for failing gym class. These countries will analyze shared data to understand trends, mitigating measures, and best practices. Essentially, theyâ€™re saying, â€œLetâ€™s not just share our snacks but also our boo-boos!â€
And letâ€™s face it, in todayâ€™s globalized world, it makes perfect sense. If one airplane has a bird-strike and itâ€™s not reported, the next plane could very well encounter a flock of angry pigeonsâ€”nobody wants that confrontation!
Time to Buckle Up! ðŸ›¡ï¸ Now, one might argue, â€œWhy havenâ€™t they done this sooner?â€ Well, letâ€™s not start throwing shade; the aviation sector is notoriously slow to adopt changes. Itâ€™s like watching your dad try to figure out the latest smartphoneâ€”conflicted expressions and occasional mutterings about â€œback in my day.â€ But here we are, five countries coming together, eager to share their data, for the sake of flying safely!
Itâ€™s refreshing to see this commitment to aviation safety, considering the really tricky business of air travel. Where else can you drink a mojito while cruising through clouds at 38,000 feet? So, hats off to our brave aviation regulatorsâ€”may your data be ever enlightening, and your skies be ever clear!
Letâ€™s Land This Plane ðŸš In a world that often feels divided, letâ€™s celebrate this cross-border collaboration. It reminds us that for all our differences, when it comes to our safetyâ€”especially at 31,000 feet in the airâ€”everyone wants the same outcome: a safe, smooth ride without any surprises.
Remember, folks, when in doubt, look down the aisle, share your tales of aerial mishaps, and keep the laughter rolling. Because if we canâ€™t find humor in near-fatal errors, whatâ€™s the point of all this?
So, hereâ€™s to the brave souls working behind the scenesâ€”on the ground and in the skyâ€”making aviation safer, one shared piece of data at a time! Cheers! ðŸ¹âœˆï¸

title: Dos detenidos y un menor herido tras un violento asalto en pleno centro - MDZ Online
text: El asalto fue este jueves a metros de la Plaza Independencia, en el centro. Dos malvivientes golpearon a la vÃ­ctima y le robaron, pero fueron detenidos. Un asalto este jueves en la Ciudad de Mendoza terminÃ³ con dos detenidos y un adolescente con lesiones. OcurriÃ³ pasado el mediodÃ­a cerca de la Plaza Independencia ), en el centro. Alrededor de las 14 la vÃ­ctima, de 15 aÃ±os, fue abordada en Espejo y Patricias Mendocinas, por dos sujetos que la golpearon en el rostro y le sacaron su celular. PolicÃ­as que circulaban por la zona fueron advertidos del hecho. A los efectivos les aportaron las caracterÃ­sticas fÃ­sicas de los ladrones y la direcciÃ³n en la que escaparon, tras lo cual los uniformados fueron tras ellos. A las pocas cuadras dieron con los delincuentes y les secuestraron el telÃ©fono robado. Los acusados, ambos de 24 aÃ±os, quedaron detenidos. author: Conley Grayson
title: chevron-right
text: {p}Humidity is slowly creeping back up, but rain chances won't ramp up until Sunday afternoon. A cold front will approach the Lowcountry late Sunday into early Monday, bringing some showers and storms. Some may have the potential to become severe; the main threat is gusty winds. Highs will be in the lower to middle 90s Sunday but with the added humidity, it will feel more like triple digits. But, we will experience some cooler temperatures again later next week! The cold front is forecasted to slide off the coast late Monday evening gifting us with some drier conditions. Tuesday and Wednesday will be mostly sunny skies with lower rain chances. Then heading into Thursday & Friday, the mornings will be partly cloudy, with the chance for isolated showers and thunderstorms in the afternoon. High pressure will be the dominate weather feature after the front rolls through, so expect a fair amount of sunshine, more seasonal temperatures and low rain chances midweek.{/p}{p}Tropical Storm Ernesto is weakening as it moves northeast and farther away from Bermuda. The only impacts we can expect in the Lowcountry will be a high risk of rip currents through the second half of the weekend.{/p}{p}Overnight, a tad warmer with mild conditions, lows 73-77.{br}Sunday, partly cloudy with isolated afternoon storms, highs 89-94.{br}Sunday night, showers & thunderstorms ending then decreasing clouds, lows 73-76.{/p}{p}Sunday Tides{/p}{p}L: 1:20am{ } { }H: 7:07am{/p}{p}L: 1:17pm{ } { } H: 7:48pm{/p}{p}Fallon Mears{br}fmears@sbgtv.com{/p}{p}{br}{/p}","forecast":{"externalServiceId":"USSC0234","zipCode":"29464","state":"South Carolina","stateAbbreviation":"SC","city":"Mount Pleasant","latitude":"32.794","longitude":"-79.862","current":{"relHumidity":70,"wndSpdMph":14,"wndDirDegr":"190","wndDirCardinal":"S","snowAmtIn":"N/A","tempF":90,"precipChance":"20","iconCode":66,"skyText":"Partly Cloudy

author: archyde
title: A diabetes drug that helps slow the progression of Parkinsonâ€™s disease
text:
France â€“ A study has found that a diabetes drug may be able to slow the progression of Parkinsonâ€™s disease, which represents an â€œimportant step forwardâ€ for treating the disease.
The study revealed that the development of motor symptoms, such as tremors and slow movement, slowed down in patients who took the treatment called lixisenatide.
The drug belongs to a group of drugs called glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonists (or GLP-1R agonists) which work by mimicking the action of a natural gut hormone that is produced after eating.
This hormone stimulates the release of insulin from the pancreas, which helps the bodyâ€™s cells absorb glucose, which is ultimately converted into energy.
There is a known link between Parkinsonâ€™s disease and type 2 diabetes, as research indicates that people with diabetes have a greater risk of developing Parkinsonâ€™s disease.
According to previous research, people with Parkinsonâ€™s disease and those with type 2 diabetes often experience a faster progression of their symptoms.
It has also been reported that people with diabetes who are treated with medications have a lower risk of developing Parkinsonâ€™s disease.
Dr Richard Wise, Director of Clinical Development at Parkinsonâ€™s Therapy, said: â€˜I am delighted to see the very positive and ground-breaking clinical outcome of the lixisenatide trial, which could have real meaning for people living with Parkinsonâ€™s disease.â€™
The LixiPark study included about 21 different research centers affiliated with the NS-Park network throughout France, and included about 156 participants who had recently been diagnosed with Parkinsonâ€™s disease. They were treated with either lixisenatide, which is licensed to treat diabetes, or a placebo along with the usual Parkinsonâ€™s medication.
The progression of motor symptoms slowed in those receiving lixisenatide treatment, while motor symptoms in participants in the placebo group continued to progress.
Results were consistent at the end of the 12-month study and two months after treatment stopped. Researchers say deeper studies are now needed.
Professors Vasilios Meissner and Olivier Rascol, lead researchers on the study, said: â€œFor 30 years, we have been trying to understand how to slow the decline associated with Parkinsonâ€™s disease over time. In this context, the positive results of the phase 2 trial of Lixipark, which showed reduced progression in motor symptoms of Parkinsonâ€™s disease over the course of a year, constitute an important step forward in the future management of the disease. We look forward to confirming these encouraging results in the future, in order to translate these results into clinical practice.â€
Masood Hussain, professor of neuroscience at the University of Oxford, said: â€œThe results of this trial are really encouraging for people with Parkinsonâ€™s disease. After a year, the patients who were taking the medication were significantly better off in their movements than those who were not taking the medication. However, the results do not provide conclusive evidence that the drug has a protective effect on the brain to effectively slow the progression of the disease.â€
He pointed out that it is necessary to take into account side effects, as nausea occurred in 46% of those receiving lixisenatide, and vomiting occurred in 13%.
Source: Independent

author: CMS Medios
title: CNDH emite recomendaciÃ³n al ISSSTE por denuncias de negligencia mÃ©dica | Noticias de MÃ©xico | EL IMPARCIAL
text: CNDH emite recomendaciÃ³n al ISSSTE por denuncias de negligencia mÃ©dica La CNDH insta al ISSSTE a llevar a cabo una reparaciÃ³n integral del daÃ±o, previa gestiÃ³n para inscribir al paciente en el Registro Nacional de VÃ­ctimas. CIUDAD DE MÃ‰XICO.- Por medio de un comunicado, la ComisiÃ³n Nacional de Derechos Humanos (CNDH) emitiÃ³ este jueves una recomendaciÃ³n al Instituto de Seguridad y Servicios Sociales de los Trabajadores del Estado ( [ISSSTE](https://www.elimparcial.com/mexico/ISSSTE-registra-ahorro-de-300-mdp-tras-suspender-pensiones-de-personas-fallecidas-20231223-0029.html)) debido a negligencias en el tratamiento de un anciano que resultaron en secuelas neurolÃ³gicas. La CNDH seÃ±alÃ³ que dos mÃ©dicos del Hospital Regional (HR) de Puebla que atendieron al paciente no consideraron un estudio clÃ­nico completo ni una evaluaciÃ³n exhaustiva. AdemÃ¡s, no establecieron un plan de tratamiento para las secuelas neurolÃ³gicas ni brindaron atenciÃ³n mÃ©dica integral para su enfermedad cerebrovascular. En su recomendaciÃ³n, la CNDH insta al ISSSTE a llevar a cabo una reparaciÃ³n integral del daÃ±o, previa gestiÃ³n para inscribir al paciente en el Registro Nacional de VÃ­ctimas. TambiÃ©n se exige atenciÃ³n por parte del servicio de NeurologÃ­a y apoyo psicolÃ³gico, asÃ­ como colaboraciÃ³n en la presentaciÃ³n y seguimiento de un proceso administrativo contra los dos funcionarios pÃºblicos involucrados. AdemÃ¡s, se requiere que el Instituto ofrezca un curso de capacitaciÃ³n sobre el derecho a la protecciÃ³n de la salud y el trato digno hacia los adultos mayores. El ISSSTE debe emitir una circular dirigida al personal de NeurologÃ­a, indicando que en ausencia del mÃ©dico asignado, cualquier personal mÃ©dico disponible debe atender a los pacientes con citas programadas, sin importar si son sus pacientes regulares o no.

author: Emily Brown
title: One of 2024's strongest meteor showers set to light up the sky this week
text: One of 2024's strongest meteor showers set to light up the sky this week Published | Last updated Featured Image Credit: Getty Stock Images We might only be three days into 2024, but one of the strongest meteor showers set to happen this entire year is already upon us. With up to 120 shooting stars being visible each hour, the Quadrantid [meteor](https://www.unilad.com/science) shower could prove to be a spectacle as it reaches its peak overnight tonight (January 3). Loadingâ€¦ The meteors appear to shoot from a region in [space](https://www.unilad.com/space) which is bounded by the constellations of Draco, BoÃ¶tes and Hercules. The area used to be known as the constellation of Quadrans Muralis, hence the name 'Quadrantids', but like Pluto being stripped of its planetary title, the area is no longer recognized as a constellation. The Quadrantid meteor shower is only visible in the Northern Hemisphere due to its position in the sky, but those who are able to see the event will likely have the best chance of spotting meteors just before dawn on 4 January. The event actually began on 26 December and is set to continue until 16 January, but according to EarthSky the predicted peak is 7:53 a.m. EST tomorrow. This makes the hours between 4:53 a.m. EST and dawn the best time to catch a glimpse of some of the shooting stars in [North America](https://www.unilad.com/us-news). In western regions, the best chance to witness the event will be earlier at night. The meteor shower can be seen with the naked eye. Credit: Fatih Kurt/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images Unfortunately, a bright last quarter moon set to rise tonight will make viewing the shower more difficult, but looking up at the sky from a dark place away from artificial lighting should hopefully make the fireballs easier to spot. Those wanting to see the shower are advised to be patient and observe the sky with a naked eye, as binoculars and telescopes can narrow the field of vision. If you're not able to get out to do some stargazing in person, the Virtual Telescope Project is hosting a [live stream of the event](https://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2022/12/30/the-2023-quadrantid-meteor-shower-online-observation-4-jan-2023). Meteor showers take place when Earth passes through the debris of a comet or asteroid, and pieces of the debris enter the Earth's atmosphere. The speed at which the debris travels causes it to burn up when it hits the atmosphere, resulting in the recognizable break streaks of light across the sky. The parent object of the Quadrantids is a rocky asteroid or 'dead comet' known as 2003 EH1, which was discovered in 2003. The shower is one of four major showers that take place each year with a sharp peak, including the Lyrids, Leonids, and Ursids. Topics: [Technology](/technology), [Space](/space), [Science](/science)

author: @WorldTribune
title: One day in Paris: Soccer violence; athletes robbed; Drag queen carries torch â€“ World Tribune: U.S. Politics and Culture, Geostrategy, China, North Korea, Corporate Watch, Media Watch
text:
Share on Facebook Follow on Facebook Add to Google+ Subscribe by Email Print This Post by WorldTribune Staff / 247 Real News July 25, 2024
The Opening Ceremonies have yet to be held, but the Paris Olympic Games have already been marked by a different kind of spectacle.
Morocco fans threw bottles and stormed the field after Argentina appeared to sscore late in added time at Wednesdayâ€™s Paris Olympics opener. / Social Media The opening match of the menâ€™s soccer tournament on Wednesday was marked by violence after fans from Morocco stormed the field and threw bottles and other objects onto the pitch after Argentina had apparently scored a game-tying goal 16 minutes into added time.
The match was delayed for two hours as the chaos was cleared and the stadium in Saint-Etienne was emptied of fans. Then, referees ruled that Argentina had been offside on the goal and it was disallowed. After another three minutes of added time following the long delay, Morocco claimed a 2-1 victory.
Argentinaâ€™s soccer federation said it issued a formal protest to world governing body FIFA to â€œtake the necessary regulatory measures for such a serious event.â€
â€œParis 2024 is working with the relevant stakeholders to understand the causes and identify appropriate actions,â€ a spokesperson for Paris organizers said.
Before Wednesdayâ€™s match, Argentina menâ€™s soccer coach Javier Mascherano said the teamâ€™s Olympic training base was robbed.
â€œThey went into training and they robbed us, in the Olympic Games,â€ Mascherano said. â€œWe didnâ€™t want to say anything after training, I donâ€™t think it helps anything. But obviously itâ€™s a bit disagreeable that these kinds of things happen.â€
Mascherano said midfielder Thiago Almadaâ€™s watch was among the items taken.
Meanwhile, there is no Olympic event for drag queens, but that didnâ€™t stop the Paris organizers from recruiting one to carry the Olympic torch.
Why would anyone watch the woke Paris Olympics.
Passing of the torch is ruined by gender politics. pic.twitter.com/Xc79lpbBWH
â€” Citizen Free Press (@CitizenFreePres) July 25, 2024

author: Anna Tong
title: OnlyFans founder, crypto foundation submit late-stage bid to buy TikTok | The Star
text:
A startup run by Tim Stokely, founder of adult content social media site OnlyFans, has partnered with a cryptocurrency foundation to submit a late-stage plan to acquire short video app TikTok from Chinese owner ByteDance, the two said on Wednesday.
The intent to bid was sent this week to the White House by Zoop, billionaire Stokely's new company, and the Hbar Foundation, which manages the Hedera cryptocurrency network's treasury.
While OnlyFans is known mainly for pornography, Zoop is mainstream and family-friendly, and gives back the majority of its revenue to those who post on the site, rewarding them for driving up user engagement.
"Our bid for TikTok isn't just about changing ownership, it's about creating a new paradigm where both creators and their communities benefit directly from the value they generate," Zoop co-founder RJ Phillips told Reuters.
The partners have been working with a consortium of investors, Phillips said. He declined to provide details on the bid or the investors backing it.
On Wednesday, Amazon also put in a last-minute offer to buy TikTok, the New York Times reported.
U.S. President Donald Trump is expected on Wednesday to consider a proposal for TikTok to decide the fate of the app used by 170 million Americans. ByteDance faces an April 5 deadline to either sell TikTok or face a U.S. ban on national security grounds under a U.S. law that took effect on January 19.
The law, passed last year with broad bipartisan support, reflects concern in Washington that TikTok's ownership makes it beholden to the Chinese government and that Beijing could use the app to conduct influence operations against the United States.
TikTok advocates argue that the ban unlawfully threatens to restrict Americans from accessing foreign media in violation of the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, which guarantees freedom of speech.
Trump postponed enforcement of the law until April 5 after taking office in January to give himself time to shepherd a deal. He has said he could extend the deadline further if needed.
The talks on TikTok have coalesced around a planfor the biggest non-Chinese investors in ByteDance to raise their stakes and acquire the app's U.S. operations, Reuters has reported.
Trump said last month his administration was in touch withfour different groupsabout a prospective TikTok deal, without identifying them.
In the closely watched sale of TikTok, the White House is playing the role of an investment bank, with U.S. Vice President JD Vance running the auction.
(Reporting from Anna Tong in San Francisco; Editing by Kenneth Li and Richard Chang)
